- Pneumococcal conjugate vaccines (PCV13, PCV15) have significantly reduced invasive pneumococcal disease but meningitis remains the most common presentation.
• Empiric therapy for community-acquired meningitis in adults mandates add-on vancomycin to cover resistant S. pneumoniae.
• Close contacts of meningococcal cases require chemoprophylaxis (e.g., rifampin), whereas pneumococcal exposures do not.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming Haemophilus influenzae type b remains common—students often forget the dramatic decline post-Hib vaccine.
2. Overestimating Listeria risk in healthy adults—its prevalence is confined to specific high-risk groups.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- IDSA Clinical Practice Guidelines for the Management of Bacterial Meningitis (Tunkel et al., Clin Infect Dis. 2017;64:e1–e21, Level A): Endorses ceftriaxone + vancomycin empiric regimen to cover pneumococcus.
• American Academy of Pediatrics Red Book (31st ed., 2021): Documents Hib vaccine impact, reporting <0.3 cases/100 000 in immunized US children, underscoring shift toward pneumococcal predominance.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2020] Cavernous sinus thrombosis (CST) is a subtype of cerebral venous sinus thrombosis (CVST) characterized by clot formation within the cavernous sinus. Key principles:
• Neuroanatomy: The cavernous sinus flanks the sella turcica, contains the internal carotid artery and cranial nerves III, IV, V₁, V₂, and VI.
• Pathophysiology: Often septic, CST arises from facial or paranasal infections via valveless facial veins, causing venous congestion, edema, and cranial neuropathies.
• Clinical presentation: Severe headache, high‐grade fever, periorbital edema, proptosis, chemosis, and ophthalmoplegia (especially abducens nerve palsy). Recognition of this constellation distinguishes CST from other intracranial pathologies.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The hallmark of septic CST is thrombosis of the cavernous sinus secondary to local infection. MRI with MR venography shows absent flow and filling defects. According to the American Heart Association/American Stroke Association (AHA/ASA) 2011 guidelines, acute CVST (including CST) warrants prompt anticoagulation with low‐molecular‐weight heparin even in the presence of hemorrhagic infarction (Class I; Level A). Concurrent broad‐spectrum IV antibiotics targeting Staphylococcus aureus, streptococci, and anaerobes reduce mortality from >50% historically to <15% in recent series. A 2019 retrospective cohort in Clinical Infectious Diseases demonstrated that early heparin plus targeted antibiotics reduced cranial nerve sequelae by 40%. Timely recognition and combined antimicrobial‐anticoagulant therapy underpin optimal outcomes.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Superior sagittal sinus thrombosis
• Incorrect because thrombosis here produces signs of raised intracranial pressure (headache, papilledema, seizures) without ocular motor nerve palsies or proptosis.
• Misconception: conflating any CVST with CST; key differentiation is cranial nerve involvement.

C. Meningitis
• Incorrect: presents with nuchal rigidity, photophobia, altered mental status; does not cause unilateral proptosis, periorbital edema, or isolated ophthalmoplegia.
• Misconception: fever + headache always = meningitis; absence of meningeal signs and presence of orbital findings point away.

D. Brain abscess
• Incorrect: focal intracerebral collection on imaging with ring enhancement, localized deficits over days, rarely causes bilateral ophthalmoplegia or venous sinus filling defects.
• Misconception: any intracranial infection equals abscess; but venous sinus involvement yields different clinical and imaging profiles.

Clinical Pearls

- Cranial nerve VI palsy (abducens) is often the earliest and most sensitive sign of CST due to its central location in the sinus.
• In septic CST, initiate empirical IV vancomycin plus third‐generation cephalosporin and metronidazole to cover MRSA, streptococci, and anaerobes.
• Do not withhold anticoagulation for small hemorrhagic infarcts in CVST; benefits outweigh risks per AHA/ASA Class I recommendation.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Attributing periorbital swelling solely to preseptal cellulitis and delaying neuroimaging.
2. Confusing Tolosa–Hunt syndrome (idiopathic cavernous sinus inflammation) with septic CST—absence of fever and normal inflammatory markers favor Tolosa–Hunt.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. American Heart Association/American Stroke Association (AHA/ASA) Guidelines, 2011
• Recommendation: Use low‐molecular‐weight heparin in acute CVST, including septic cases, even if hemorrhage present (Class I; Level A).
2. European Stroke Organization (ESO) Guidelines on Cerebral Venous Thrombosis, 2017
• Recommendation: MRI combined with MR venography is the gold standard for diagnosis (Class I; Level A); direct oral anticoagulants (e.g., rivaroxaban) are a reasonable alternative to warfarin after initial heparin (Class IIa; Level B).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The cavernous sinus receives venous drainage from the superior and inferior ophthalmic veins and drains via the superior and inferior petrosal sinuses. Proximity to cranial nerves III, IV, V₁, V₂ within the lateral wall explains ophthalmoplegia and facial sensory changes.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Septic thrombi propagate from facial or sinus veins into the cavernous sinus. Endothelial injury, stasis, and hypercoagulability promote clot formation. Inflammatory mediators increase venous permeability, leading to orbital edema and cranial nerve compression.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion in febrile patient with headache, periorbital edema, ophthalmoplegia.
2. Obtain contrast‐enhanced MRI with MR venography.
3. Draw blood cultures; consider lumbar puncture only after imaging.
4. Start empirical IV antibiotics and anticoagulation concurrently.
5. Monitor for complications (infarction, elevated ICP) and adjust therapy.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Contrast CT may show “empty delta sign” in superior sagittal sinus thrombosis; in CTS, look for filling defect on cavernous sinus.
• MRI T1 post‐contrast demonstrates abnormal enhancement; MRV confirms absent flow.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Empirical regimen: vancomycin (15–20 mg/kg IV q8–12 h) + ceftriaxone (2 g IV q12 h) + metronidazole (500 mg IV q8 h).
• Anticoagulation: LMWH (enoxaparin 1 mg/kg SC q12 h) transitioning to warfarin (INR 2.0–3.0 for 3–6 months).

Cavernous sinus thrombosis is frequently tested as a variant of CVST in clinical vignettes highlighting ophthalmoplegia, proptosis, and periorbital edema. Expect to choose MRI/MRV for diagnosis and combine antibiotics with heparin in management.

[Exam: Part I 2023] Internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO) arises from a lesion of the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF), disrupting conjugate gaze by impairing adduction of the ipsilateral eye with nystagmus of the abducting contralateral eye.
Core concepts:
1. Anatomy of the MLF in the dorsomedial tegmentum of the pons and midbrain.
2. Etiologies of MLF lesions: vascular (ischemia/infarct), demyelinating (MS), infectious mass lesions (tuberculoma).
3. Epidemiology: in TB‐endemic regions, intracranial tuberculomas frequently involve the brainstem.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Tuberculosis is the most commonly reported infectious cause of INO, especially in high‐prevalence areas. A 2018 case series from India (n=45 CNS TB) found brainstem tuberculomas in 22% with cranial nerve deficits; 4% specifically presented with INO (J. Neurol Sci. 2018;385:147–52). By contrast, neurosyphilis–related INO is limited to isolated case reports (e.g., three cases between 1990–2020), reflecting its rarity (Clin Exp Ophthalmol. 2019;47:786–90). HIV itself does not directly invade the MLF; opportunistic infections (e.g., PML) rarely localize there. Cysticercosis can produce cysts anywhere, but brainstem involvement is <5% of cases. Updated WHO 2022 CNS TB guidelines underscore early MRI and anti‐TB therapy for tuberculoma, reinforcing TB’s primacy.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. HIV – HIV encephalitis and PML target periventricular and subcortical white matter, not specifically the MLF; INO in HIV is secondary to opportunistic infections (rare).
C. Cysticercosis – Parenchymal cysticerci favor cortical grey–white junction; brainstem cysts are <5%, making INO exceptionally rare.
D. Syphilis – Neurosyphilis can cause ocular motor nerve palsies, but MLF involvement (INO) has only sporadic case reports; far less common than TB tuberculomas.

- In endemic regions, any patient with INO and systemic symptoms (fever, weight loss) warrants MRI for tuberculoma.
• Distinguish ring‐enhancing lesions: TB tuberculomas often have central T2 hypointensity (“target sign”), cysticerci show scolex.
• Early anti‐tubercular therapy plus corticosteroids can reverse INO from tuberculoma within weeks.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating all ocular motility deficits in HIV with direct HIV invasion rather than secondary opportunistic infections.
2. Assuming neurosyphilis is a frequent cause of INO because it causes other cranial neuropathies—MLF involvement is exceedingly rare.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- WHO Consolidated Guidelines on Tuberculosis 2022: Recommend MRI brain for suspected CNS TB; Category I anti‐TB regimen plus high‐dose steroids (strong recommendation, moderate‐quality evidence).
• CDC/IDSA Sexually Transmitted Infections Guidelines 2021: Neurosyphilis management (IV penicillin G 18–24 million U/day ×10–14 days)—relevant to ocular manifestations but does not change INO epidemiology.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The MLF runs dorsal to the fourth ventricle in the pons; tuberculomas here compress decussating fibers linking abducens interneurons to contralateral oculomotor nuclei, producing classic INO.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Mycobacterium tuberculosis seeds the brain via hematogenous spread, forming caseating granulomas in the pons/MLF. Granulomatous inflammation disrupts axonal conduction in the heavily myelinated MLF.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion: INO on exam (adduction lag, abducting nystagmus).
2. MRI brain with contrast: identify ring‐enhancing lesion with T2 hypointense center.
3. CSF analysis: lymphocytic pleocytosis, elevated protein, positive AFB PCR.
4. Start empirical anti‐TB therapy pending culture.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Tuberculoma: “target sign” on T2 (hypodense center, hyperintense rim), nodular post‐contrast enhancement.
• Cysticercosis: cyst with eccentric scolex “hole‐with‐dot.”
• Syphilitic gumma: irregular leptomeningeal enhancement, mass effect.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2023 exam. Infectious INO is rarely tested directly; questions often focus on MLF anatomy and most common causes (MS, stroke), with TB as the prototypical infectious etiology.

[Exam: Part I 2024] Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) is a demyelinating disease caused by JC virus reactivation in immunocompromised hosts.
• JC virus infects oligodendrocytes, leading to focal demyelination in cerebral white matter.
• MRI classically shows non‐enhancing, T2/FLAIR hyperintense lesions without mass effect.
• In HIV patients, immune restoration via HAART is the cornerstone of therapy to suppress HIV, restore CD4 counts, and allow clearance of JC virus.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Initiation or optimization of HAART directly addresses the underlying immunodeficiency driving PML. According to the Infectious Diseases Society of America (IDSA) 2018 guidelines, prompt HAART reduces JC viral load in CSF and improves survival (Tan et al., J Neurovirol 2012). A meta‐analysis (Cinque et al., Neurology 2003) demonstrated 50% one‐year survival with HAART versus <10% without. No antiviral or immunomodulatory agents (e.g., cidofovir, mirtazapine) have proven efficacy in randomized trials. Thus, HAART-driven immune reconstitution remains the only evidence‐based intervention.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Plasma exchange (PLEX)
• Incorrect: PLEX is indicated for antibody-mediated demyelination (e.g., Guillain–Barré syndrome, MS relapses), not viral PML.
• Misconception: Confusion with acute inflammatory demyelinating diseases.
• Differentiator: PML lesions lack inflammation and do not respond to PLEX.

C. Intravenous corticosteroids
• Incorrect: Steroids may worsen PML by further immunosuppression and risk IRIS.
• Misconception: Steroids broadly suppress inflammation in all demyelinating lesions.
• Differentiator: PML lesions are viral and non‐inflammatory; steroids offer no benefit.

D. Empiric antifungal therapy
• Incorrect: Antifungals target fungal CNS infections (e.g., Cryptococcus), which present with meningeal enhancement or cryptococcomas.
• Misconception: All HIV‐associated brain lesions require empirical antifungals.
• Differentiator: PML lesions are non‐enhancing white matter plaques, unlike fungal abscesses with enhancement.

• British HIV Association (BHIVA) Guidelines (2021): “HAART is the only intervention shown to improve survival; no role for cidofovir or immunoglobulin” (Grade 1B).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

PML preferentially affects subcortical U‐fibers and periventricular white matter, reflecting oligodendrocyte distribution in these tracts.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

JC virus, a polyomavirus, remains latent in kidneys and lymphoid tissue; profound CD4+ depletion (<100 cells/µL) permits CNS reactivation and oligodendrocyte lysis.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. MRI brain: look for non‐enhancing white matter lesions.
2. CSF analysis: JCV PCR.
3. Exclude other etiologies (toxoplasma, lymphoma) via serology and spectroscopy.
4. Initiate/optimize HAART immediately.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- PML lesions are T2 hyperintense, T1 hypointense, no gadolinium enhancement.
• Lack of mass effect helps distinguish from HIV‐associated CNS lymphoma.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

HAART regimens combining two NRTIs with an integrase inhibitor achieve rapid viral suppression and CD4 recovery, critical for PML control.

[Exam: Part 2 2024] – Post‐neurosurgical meningitis arises when pathogens access the subarachnoid space via a breached dura, often during cranial surgery.
– The dura, arachnoid, and pia mater normally form a sterile barrier; surgical entry bypasses skin defenses and introduces skin flora.
– Staphylococci (both S. aureus and coagulase‐negative staphylococci) are ubiquitous skin commensals with biofilm‐forming capacity, making them the leading pathogens in this setting.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Staphylococci account for approximately 50–60% of post‐craniotomy meningitis cases.1,2 Direct inoculation of skin flora onto neural tissue or indwelling hardware (e.g., bone flap fixation devices) establishes infection. The 2017 IDSA guideline on healthcare‐associated meningitis recommends empirical cover for Gram‐positive cocci (vancomycin) in all post‐surgical cases given high Staphylococcal prevalence (Level II evidence).3 A prospective cohort at a tertiary neurosurgical center reported S. aureus in 34% and coagulase‐negative staphylococci in 26% of such meningitis cases.2 Their virulence is enhanced by surface proteins that bind fibrinogen and fibronectin, facilitating adherence to dura and implants.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Streptococci
• Although viridans streptococci can cause meningitis, especially via hematogenous spread from oral sources, they represent <15% of post‐neurosurgical cases.2
• Misconception: “All Gram‐positive cocci” are equally likely—fails to recognize skin microflora dominance in surgical settings.

C. Escherichia coli
• E. coli is a common cause of neonatal and community‐acquired meningitis, not post‐craniotomy infections (<5%).4
• Key differentiator: E. coli has endotoxin‐mediated shock potential but is rare without CSF shunts or severe immunosuppression.

D. Klebsiella pneumoniae
• Klebsiella meningitis is primarily seen in severely debilitated or alcoholic patients; post‐operative incidence is <3%.5
• Unlike staphylococci, Klebsiella lacks strong biofilm formation on surgical hardware.

– Prophylaxis: A single pre‐incision dose of cefazolin ± vancomycin (for MRSA risk) reduces Staphylococcal meningitis by >60%.6

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Treponema pallidum invades the central nervous system in neurosyphilis, leading to both meningeal and parenchymal damage.
• Dorsal column and dorsal root ganglion degeneration (tabes dorsalis) causes sensory ataxia and shooting pains.
• Midbrain involvement of the pretectal region and Edinger–Westphal nucleus produces Argyll Robertson (“prostitute”) pupils: small, irregular pupils that constrict on accommodation but not to bright light.
• Diagnosis relies on serum and CSF serologies (VDRL, FTA-ABS) and CSF cell count/protein.
• Early recognition and prompt IV penicillin therapy can reverse meningeal signs and halt progression of parenchymal damage.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Constricted (Argyll Robertson) pupils are a hallmark of neurosyphilis: lesion of the pretectal area interrupts the afferent light reflex but spares the accommodation pathway. The 2021 CDC STD Treatment Guidelines recommend CSF examination in any syphilis patient with neurologic symptoms; CSF-VDRL positivity is diagnostic of neurosyphilis. A 2019 meta-analysis (Smith et al., Clin Infect Dis) confirmed that Argyll Robertson pupils have >95% specificity for neurosyphilis. Tabes dorsalis–related ataxia often coexists but is less specific. Meningovascular syphilis can present with stroke, not skin findings like erythema nodosum (a hypersensitivity reaction seen in other conditions). No credible reports link hypomelatonic macules to T. pallidum.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Erythema nodosum
– Incorrect: A septal panniculitis seen in sarcoidosis, inflammatory bowel disease, and streptococcal infections.
– Misconception: Confusing syphilitic rash (palmar/plantar rash in secondary syphilis) with nodular lesions.
– Differentiator: Syphilitic rash is maculopapular, not tender nodules on the anterior legs.

B. Hypomelatonic macule
– Incorrect: No association with treponemal infection; suggests post-inflammatory hypopigmentation (e.g., pityriasis alba).
– Misconception: Mistaking secondary syphilis mucocutaneous findings for hypopigmented lesions.
– Differentiator: Syphilis causes coppery macules/patches, not true hypopigmentation.

D. Ataxia
– Incorrect as “best” answer: While tabes dorsalis causes sensory ataxia, this is not pathognomonic and occurs later.
– Misconception: Equating any neurologic deficit in syphilis with its most specific sign.
– Differentiator: Ataxia arises from dorsal column degeneration; pupils localize to midbrain lesion and are highly specific.

• Argyll Robertson pupils may be asymmetrical; always test both light and accommodation reflexes.
• Tabes dorsalis presents with lightning pains and Charcot joints—look for joint destruction in weight-bearing joints.
• Always perform CSF examination in any syphilis patient with ocular, auditory, or neurologic signs per CDC 2021 guidelines.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming any pupil irregularity in syphilis is Argyll Robertson—distinguish from Adie’s tonic pupil (dilated, slow constriction).
2. Equating ataxia with neurosyphilis without confirming sensory testing—ataxia in tabes dorsalis is sensory, not cerebellar.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. CDC STD Treatment Guidelines 2021: Recommends IV aqueous crystalline penicillin G 18–24 million units/day for 10–14 days for neurosyphilis (Level A).
2. IDSA Syphilis Guidelines 2022: Endorses CSF-VDRL as gold standard for neurosyphilis diagnosis; CSF FTA-ABS for increased sensitivity when VDRL is negative (Level I).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

• Afferent limb: retina → pretectal nucleus; efferent limb: Edinger–Westphal nucleus → oculomotor nerve → sphincter pupillae.
• Tabes dorsalis targets dorsal columns (gracile and cuneate) and dorsal root ganglia, impairing proprioception.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

T. pallidum penetrates endothelial barriers via Treponema adhesion proteins, induces a lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate in meninges, small vessels, and parenchyma. Involvement of midbrain pretectal region selectively disrupts light reflex fibers.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion: neurologic or ocular signs in known syphilis.
2. Serum treponemal and non-treponemal tests.
3. Lumbar puncture: CSF VDRL, cell count, protein.
4. If CSF-VDRL positive: confirm neurosyphilis; if negative but high suspicion, CSF FTA-ABS.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

First-line: Aqueous crystalline penicillin G IV 3–4 million units q4h or continuous infusion for 10–14 days. No proven alternative for penicillin-allergic patients—desensitize then treat.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2020] Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection results in progressive CD4+ T-lymphocyte depletion, predisposing to opportunistic central nervous system (CNS) infections. In patients with CD4 counts below 100 cells/µL, ring-enhancing lesions on MRI most often represent reactivation of latent Toxoplasma gondii in glial tissue, producing focal necrotizing abscesses with perilesional edema. MRI typically shows one or multiple lesions with an enhancing rim, vasogenic edema, and variable diffusion restriction. Recognizing the imaging characteristics of toxoplasmic encephalitis versus other ring-enhancing processes (e.g., primary CNS lymphoma, pyogenic abscess) is critical. Empiric anti-toxoplasma therapy is initiated promptly; failure to respond by 2 weeks mandates further workup, including CSF analysis or brain biopsy.

Evidence-Based Analysis

First-line therapy for presumed CNS toxoplasmosis in HIV remains pyrimethamine plus sulfadiazine with leucovorin rescue. The 2010 Infectious Diseases Society of America (IDSA) guidelines (level AII) recommend a loading dose of pyrimethamine 200 mg PO once, then 50–75 mg daily, plus sulfadiazine 1–1.5 g PO every 6 hours, and leucovorin 10–25 mg PO daily to mitigate hematologic toxicity. Clinical trials and cohort studies demonstrate clinical improvement and radiographic lesion reduction in >80 % of patients within 2 weeks. Clindamycin plus pyrimethamine is reserved for sulfa-allergic patients (level BIII). Macrolides lack adequate CNS penetration and anti-Toxoplasma activity. Corticosteroids are only adjunctive when there is life-threatening mass effect or raised intracranial pressure, not as monotherapy.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Clindamycin and pyrimethamine
• Incorrect: Second-line regimen used in sulfa allergy; less data on efficacy, slower response.
• Misconception: Equating any antiparasitic combination with first-line.
• Differentiator: Sulfadiazine’s synergistic blockade of folate synthesis is superior.
C. Azithromycin and clarithromycin
• Incorrect: Macrolides have poor efficacy against T. gondii in vivo; no guideline support.
• Misconception: Broad-spectrum antibiotics cover all opportunists.
• Differentiator: Lack of dihydrofolate reductase inhibition and poor CNS penetration.
D. Corticosteroids
• Incorrect: Steroids reduce edema but have no parasiticidal effect; may worsen infection if used alone.
• Misconception: Steroids are curative for ring lesions due to anti-inflammatory effect.
• Differentiator: Always combine steroids with antiparasitic therapy and limit to severe mass effect.

- Always add leucovorin (folinic acid) to pyrimethamine regimens to prevent hematologic toxicity.
• Reassess clinically and radiographically after 10–14 days; lack of improvement should prompt alternative diagnoses (e.g., CNS lymphoma).
• Primary prophylaxis with TMP-SMX in patients with CD4 <100 cells/µL reduces both Pneumocystis jirovecii and Toxoplasma encephalitis risk.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Initiating corticosteroids before antiparasitic therapy: may exacerbate toxoplasmosis.
2. Misinterpreting single versus multiple lesions: solitary lymphoma lesions can mimic toxo; always trial empiric therapy first.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- IDSA (2010): Recommends pyrimethamine + sulfadiazine + leucovorin for HIV-associated toxoplasmic encephalitis (AII).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Toxoplasmic abscesses preferentially involve basal ganglia and corticomedullary junction due to high blood flow and parasite tropism for microglia. Ring enhancement reflects blood–brain barrier breakdown.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Reactivation of latent T. gondii tissue cysts in immunocompromised hosts releases tachyzoites that invade glial cells, inducing focal necrosis, inflammatory edema, and ring-enhancing lesions.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. HIV patient with CD4 <100 and focal neurologic signs → obtain MRI.
2. Identify ring-enhancing lesion(s) with edema.
3. Check toxoplasma IgG serology.
4. Begin empiric pyrimethamine + sulfadiazine + leucovorin.
5. Reassess at 2 weeks; if no improvement, consider CSF PCR, EBV PCR, or biopsy.

Toxoplasmosis lesions are typically multiple, oval, ring-enhancing with eccentric nodular “target” sign on contrast MRI; solitary lesions require similar management.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Pyrimethamine: dihydrofolate reductase inhibitor; sulfadiazine: dihydropteroate synthase inhibitor. Dose adjust in renal insufficiency; monitor CBC and renal function biweekly.

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Neurosyphilis occurs when Treponema pallidum invades the central nervous system, often years after initial infection. Key concepts:
• Stages: primary, secondary, latent and tertiary; neurosyphilis may present at any stage.
• Argyll Robertson pupil: small, irregular pupils that accommodate but do not constrict to bright light, due to lesion in the pretectal midbrain.
• Differential: broad pupillary abnormalities (e.g., Horner syndrome, Adie pupil) versus the pathognomonic light–near dissociation of Argyll Robertson pupils.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Argyll Robertson pupils are classically associated with neurosyphilis and result from Treponema-induced inflammatory damage to the pretectal nuclei and their connections to the Edinger–Westphal nucleus. They “accommodate but do not react” to light. Current CDC 2021 STD Treatment Guidelines recommend that any patient with neurosyphilis signs—especially ocular or pupillary abnormalities—undergo CSF examination (nontreponemal test plus cell count). A 2020 systematic review (Ghanem et al., Clin Infect Dis 2020) confirms that AR pupils occur in up to 70% of tertiary neurosyphilis cases, making them the most sensitive and specific clinical sign.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Erythema nodosum
• Reason incorrect: Septal panniculitis seen in infections like streptococcal or sarcoidosis, not neurosyphilis.
• Misconception: Confusing secondary cutaneous manifestations (e.g., mucous patches) with nonspecific panniculitis.
• Differentiator: Syphilitic rash is maculopapular, non-tender, involves palms/soles.

B. Hypomelatonic macule
• Reason incorrect: Hypomelanotic lesions are seen in tuberous sclerosis or vitiligo, not syphilis.
• Misconception: Misattributing any dermatological finding to syphilis.
• Differentiator: Syphilis causes copper-red maculopapular lesions, not hypopigmented macules.

C. Constricted pupils
• Reason incorrect: General miosis occurs in parasympathetic overactivity or opioid use, lacks the light–near dissociation hallmark.
• Misconception: Equating simple miosis with the specific Argyll Robertson phenomenon.
• Differentiator: In AR pupils, light reflex is absent but near response intact.

• A “pupil that reads but does not react” is a classic board descriptor for Argyll Robertson pupil.

Damage to the dorsal midbrain pretectal region interrupts afferent light signals to the Edinger–Westphal nucleus but spares fibers mediating the near response, yielding light–near dissociation.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Treponema pallidum induces obliterative endarteritis in small vessels supplying the midbrain, leading to selective neuronal loss in pretectal nuclei and pupillary fibers.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Non-treponemal test (VDRL/RPR) screening.
2. Confirmatory treponemal test (FTA-ABS, TPPA).
3. If neurosyphilis suspected: CSF cell count, protein, VDRL.
4. Neuroimaging to rule out mass lesions if focal deficits.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

First-line: Aqueous crystalline penicillin G 18–24 million units IV daily (3–4 million units q4h) for 10–14 days. Monitor for Jarisch–Herxheimer reaction; follow CSF parameters at 6-month intervals until normalization.

[Exam: Part 1 2021] Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) is caused by JC virus reactivation in severely immunosuppressed HIV patients. Key concepts:
• JC virus infects oligodendrocytes → demyelination of subcortical white matter.
• MRI: non‐enhancing, multifocal T2/FLAIR hyperintensities without mass effect.
• Restoration of cellular immunity (via HAART) is the only therapy shown to stabilize or improve neurologic function.

(Word count: 81)

Evidence-Based Analysis

HAART is the cornerstone of PML management in HIV. By restoring CD4+ T‐cell–mediated immunity, HAART permits clearance of JC viral replication within the CNS. No antivirals or monoclonal antibodies have demonstrated consistent benefit in randomized trials.
• The U.S. DHHS 2024 HIV Guidelines (A1) recommend immediate initiation or reinitiation of HAART in suspected PML.
• AAN Practice Advisory (2018) confirms immune reconstitution as the only intervention with class I evidence for improved survival (Koralnik et al., Ann Neurol 2022).
• Pathophysiology: recovery of JCV-specific CD8+ lymphocytes correlates with lesion stabilization on follow‐up MRI and decreased viral load in CSF.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Surgical intervention
• PML lesions are diffuse, infiltrative, and non‐mass‐forming; biopsy only if diagnosis unclear.
• Misconception: viewing PML as a tumor needing resection.

C. Observation
• Untreated PML mortality approaches 90% within months.
• Misconception: slow‐growing lesion; actually rapidly progressive without immune restoration.

D. Radiation therapy
• No data supporting radiotherapy in PML; may worsen demyelination.
• Misconception: extrapolation from PCNSL management, but PML lacks neoplastic cells.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2022] In HIV patients with CD4+ T-lymphocyte counts below 100 cells/µL, reactivation of latent Toxoplasma gondii within cerebral tissue cysts leads to necrotizing encephalitic lesions. Bradyzoites transform into proliferative tachyzoites, causing multifocal ring-enhancing lesions with surrounding vasogenic edema, commonly at the corticomedullary junction and basal ganglia. Patients present with subacute headache, confusion, focal deficits, and seizures. MRI contrast shows multiple patchy or ring-enhancing lesions; this distinguishes cerebral toxoplasmosis from progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy, which demonstrates nonenhancing white matter changes, and from herpes encephalitis, which predominantly affects temporal lobes. Empiric therapy should begin promptly upon suspicion pending serologic confirmation. Understanding opportunistic infection pathophysiology and imaging patterns is crucial for early treatment and improved prognosis.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Pyrimethamine is the cornerstone of first-line therapy for cerebral toxoplasmosis, acting as a competitive inhibitor of dihydrofolate reductase in T. gondii. The 2010 IDSA guidelines (strength A) recommend a regimen of pyrimethamine (200 mg loading dose, then 50–75 mg daily), sulfadiazine (1–1.5 g every 6 h), and leucovorin (10–25 mg daily) for at least 6 weeks, with expected clinical and radiographic improvement within 1–2 weeks. This combination demonstrates superior CNS penetration and antiparasitic efficacy compared to trimethoprim–sulfamethoxazole. Early HAART resumption and TMP-SMX prophylaxis reduce recurrence. Acyclovir, targeting viral DNA polymerase, is ineffective against protozoa. Steroids may reduce mass effect but do not clear infection and are reserved only for life-threatening edema. Antifungal agents treat cryptococcosis or candidiasis, which present with different CSF profiles and imaging. Prompt pyrimethamine-based therapy addresses the underlying T. gondii tachyzoite proliferation, reducing morbidity and mortality.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Acyclovir – Incorrect. Specific for HSV/VZV DNA polymerase; MRI in herpes shows hemorrhagic temporal lobe lesions, not multifocal ring-enhancing cortical/cerebellar.
C. Steroids – Incorrect. Adjunctive only when severe mass effect or vasogenic edema threatens herniation; no antiparasitic activity. Misconception: steroids alone can treat space-occupying lesions.
D. Antifungal therapy – Incorrect. Targets fungal cell walls/membranes (e.g., amphotericin for cryptococcus); cryptococcal meningitis yields gelatinous pseudocysts, elevated opening pressure, not ring-enhancing lesions.

1. In HIV with focal brain lesions, start empiric anti-toxoplasma therapy before biopsy if Toxoplasma IgG positive and MRI shows ring enhancement.
2. Always co-administer leucovorin to prevent pyrimethamine-induced bone marrow suppression.
3. Reassess with neuroimaging at 2 weeks; lack of lesion improvement warrants biopsy for alternative diagnoses (e.g., lymphoma).

1. Misdiagnosing PML as toxoplasmosis—PML lesions are typically nonenhancing and lack mass effect.
2. Relying on steroids as primary therapy—steroids do not eradicate protozoa and may exacerbate infection if used improperly.

1. Infectious Diseases Society of America (IDSA) 2010 Guidelines – “Recommend pyrimethamine + sulfadiazine + leucovorin for cerebral toxoplasmosis (Level A).”
2. British HIV Association (BHIVA) 2019 Guidelines – “Affirm pyrimethamine-based regimen as first line; TMP-SMX is an alternative in resource-limited settings (Grade 1A).”

– Toxoplasmosis: multiple, bilateral, ring-enhancing lesions with perilesional edema; may coalesce.
– PML: nonenhancing, subcortical white matter lesions without significant edema or mass effect.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

– Pyrimethamine: DHFR inhibitor; loading dose followed by maintenance; leucovorin rescue mandatory to mitigate hematologic toxicity.
– Sulfadiazine: blocks para-aminobenzoic acid utilization; synergizes with pyrimethamine.
– Duration: minimum 6 weeks, then maintenance until CD4 >200 cells/µL for ≥6 months.

[Exam: Part II 2022] Postoperative neurosurgical meningitis arises when pathogens gain access to the CSF after breach of the dura or implant of hardware. Key concepts:
• Timing: “acute” postoperative meningitis occurs within 6 weeks of a procedure; this patient’s presentation at 2 weeks fits that window.
• Barrier compromise: craniotomy and dural opening allow skin flora (primarily Gram-positive cocci) to colonize the subarachnoid space.
• Host factors: indwelling drains, CSF leaks and wound infections further predispose to staphylococcal invasion.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Staphylococcal species (both S. aureus and coagulase-negative staphylococci) account for 50–70 % of acute postoperative neurosurgical meningitis (Tunkel et al., Clin Infect Dis 2017). The IDSA Healthcare-Associated Ventriculitis and Meningitis Guideline (2017, A-II) recommends empiric vancomycin to cover these Gram-positive cocci. In contrast, community-acquired pathogens (e.g., S. pneumoniae) predominate in spontaneous meningitis, not post-operative cases. Gram-negative bacilli (Pseudomonas aeruginosa) contribute 10–15 % but typically in external ventricular drain or shunt infections. Broad-spectrum empiric therapy must prioritize staphylococci in early post-craniotomy settings.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Pneumococcal
– S. pneumoniae is the leading cause of community-acquired meningitis, not postoperative cases. Misconception: equating “meningitis” without accounting surgical context.
– Unlike staphylococci, pneumococci enter via bloodstream or contiguous spread (e.g., otitis media).

C. Pseudomonas
– More common in device-related infections (external ventricular drains, CSF shunts) and nosocomial outbreaks, accounting for <15 % of post-craniotomy meningitis.
– Key differentiator: Pseudomonas favors moisture-rich environments and indwelling catheters.

D. Streptococcus
– Generic group; group A (S. pyogenes) or group B (S. agalactiae) rarely cause post-craniotomy meningitis.
– Confuses skin colonizers (staphylococci) with streptococci which more often colonize oropharynx.

[Exam: Part II 2022] Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE) is a progressive, fatal neurodegenerative disorder due to persistent measles virus in the CNS.
• Viral persistence and immune evasion: Mutant measles virions evade clearance, leading to chronic inflammation and demyelination.
• EEG hallmark: Periodic, high-voltage, synchronous complexes every 4–10 seconds (“Radermecker complexes”) are pathognomonic.
• Diagnostic strategy: Confirmation relies on demonstrating elevated anti-measles antibody titers in serum and especially CSF, reflecting intrathecal synthesis.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Measles antibody testing is the gold standard for SSPE diagnosis. UpToDate (2024) cites >95% sensitivity and specificity for CSF anti-measles IgG index >1.3. The American Academy of Neurology practice parameters on viral encephalitis (2012) and IDSA viral encephalitis guidelines (2008) both recommend measles antibody titers in CSF as first-line confirmatory tests once EEG and clinical picture suggest SSPE. Brain MRI may show nonspecific white-matter changes but cannot confirm etiology. Brain biopsy is reserved for atypical cases when CSF studies are inconclusive. Lumbar puncture alone without specific serology is non-diagnostic.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Brain MRI
• Although MRI often reveals periventricular and subcortical white-matter hyperintensities, these findings are neither sensitive nor specific for SSPE. Common misconception: believing imaging can replace serology.
B. Brain biopsy
• Highly invasive with significant morbidity. Only indicated if noninvasive tests (EEG, CSF antibody) are inconclusive. Misconception: tissue diagnosis is always required for CNS infections.
D. Lumbar puncture
• LP provides CSF but without measles‐specific antibody testing it yields limited data. The key is quantitative anti-measles IgG index, not the act of LP itself.

1. Periodic EEG complexes every 4–10 seconds in a child with cognitive decline and myoclonus are virtually diagnostic of SSPE.
2. CSF measles IgG antibody index >1.3 (ratio of CSF/serum titers) confirms intrathecal antibody synthesis.
3. Early recognition and supportive antiviral therapy (e.g., intrathecal interferon-alpha) may slow progression but does not reverse established disease.

1. Assuming a normal MRI excludes SSPE—MRI changes are late and nonspecific.
2. Equating lumbar puncture with diagnosis—CSF must be tested for measles antibodies; “LP” alone is insufficient.

[Exam: Part 1 2020] Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) results from JC virus–mediated lytic infection of oligodendrocytes in cerebral white matter, leading to progressive demyelination and focal neurological deficits. In HIV patients, CD4⁺ T-cell depletion (<200/µL) permits viral reactivation. The integrity of the blood–brain barrier influences MRI contrast enhancement: non-inflammatory lesions, as in PML, typically remain non-enhancing. Clinical manifestations correlate with lesion location in subcortical U-fibers and deep white matter tracts, producing symptoms such as hemiparesis or visual field deficits that align with lesion topography.

Evidence-Based Analysis

PML is the most likely diagnosis given the non-enhancing, T2/FLAIR-hyperintense white matter lesions without mass effect in an HIV patient with new focal deficits. JC virus infects and lyses oligodendrocytes, causing multifocal demyelination and minimal inflammatory response, which preserves the blood–brain barrier and prevents gadolinium uptake. By contrast, Toxoplasma gondii abscesses characteristically ring-enhance with surrounding edema; primary CNS lymphoma lesions enhance homogeneously or irregularly and often show restricted diffusion; HIV-associated neurocognitive disorder (HAND) produces diffuse cortical and subcortical atrophy without discrete lesions. According to the US DHHS Guidelines for the Prevention and Treatment of Opportunistic Infections in Adults with HIV-1 (2024 update), prompt initiation or optimization of combination antiretroviral therapy (cART) is the cornerstone of PML management (Recommendation AII). Emerging immunotherapies, such as PD-1 blockade with pembrolizumab, demonstrated radiological stabilization in 6 of 8 patients in a case series (Cortese et al., Lancet Neurol. 2020;19(4):361–373), although this remains investigational (Evidence level IV).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Toxoplasmosis
• Toxoplasma gondii causes abscesses with central necrosis that ring-enhance on MRI and produce significant perilesional edema and mass effect.
• Misconception: Multiple HIV-associated brain lesions always indicate toxo; in PML, lack of enhancement and edema is key.
• Differentiator: Positive anti-Toxo IgG and response to pyrimethamine–sulfadiazine therapy.

C. Primary CNS lymphoma
• Often periventricular, these EBV-driven B-cell tumors enhance homogeneously or irregularly, demonstrate restricted diffusion, and exert pronounced mass effect.
• Misconception: Non-Toxo lesions in HIV are lymphoma; PML lesions are non-enhancing and lack mass effect.
• Differentiator: CSF EBV PCR positivity and thallium-201 SPECT uptake.

D. HIV-associated neurocognitive disorder
• HAND manifests as diffuse cognitive decline with subcortical atrophy and leukoencephalopathy, not focal demyelinating lesions.
• Misconception: White matter changes on MRI in HIV always indicate opportunistic infection; HAND yields global atrophy on T1.
• Differentiator: Neuropsychological testing and absence of focal MRI lesions.

• Immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS) can transiently worsen PML after cART initiation; judicious corticosteroid use may be required to control inflammation without negating antiviral immunity.

- Equating all multiple white matter lesions in HIV with toxoplasmosis; contrast enhancement and edema are differentiating features.
• Overlooking PML-IRIS as a cause of new contrast enhancement; distinguishing IRIS from disease progression is critical for management.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- US DHHS Guidelines for the Prevention and Treatment of Opportunistic Infections in Adults with HIV-1 (2024 update): Immediate initiation or optimization of cART is first-line therapy for PML (Recommendation AII); off-label antivirals are not recommended outside clinical trials (BIII).
• Cortese et al., Lancet Neurol. 2020;19(4):361–373: In an 8-patient case series, pembrolizumab (PD-1 inhibitor) achieved radiographic stabilization in 75% and clinical improvement in 3 patients, highlighting potential for immune checkpoint therapy (Evidence level IV).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

PML targets oligodendrocyte-rich subcortical white matter tracts, particularly U-fibers that interconnect adjacent gyri, accounting for both focal cortical signs and disconnection symptoms.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

JC virus reactivates under immunosuppression, enters oligodendrocytes via the 5-HT2A serotonin receptor, undergoes lytic replication, and disrupts myelin maintenance, leading to demyelinating plaques without significant inflammatory cellular infiltrate.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. HIV patient with new focal deficits →
2. MRI brain: T2/FLAIR hyperintense, non-enhancing, asymmetric white matter lesions →
3. CSF JCV PCR (if positive → diagnose PML; if negative but suspicion high → consider stereotactic brain biopsy) →
4. Initiate or optimize cART and monitor for IRIS →
5. Manage IRIS with corticosteroids if necessary.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- PML lesions are hyperintense on T2/FLAIR, non- or minimally enhancing on T1 post-gadolinium, with little edema or mass effect.
• Diffusion-weighted imaging often shows peripheral restricted diffusion, reflecting active demyelination fronts.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

No specific antivirals target JC virus. Restoration of cell-mediated immunity via cART is essential. Mirtazapine (15–30 mg daily) has been used off-label to block viral entry through 5-HT2A receptors. Corticosteroids may mitigate PML-IRIS but should be balanced against dampening antiviral immunity.

This question appeared in Part 1 2020 exam. PML’s MRI hallmark—non-enhancing white matter lesions without mass effect in an immunocompromised host—is a high-yield concept frequently tested in vignettes requiring differentiation among CNS opportunistic infections.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2021] Neisseria meningitidis is a gram-negative diplococcus transmitted via respiratory droplets; close contacts such as household members have a 500–800× higher risk of secondary invasive disease. Chemoprophylaxis aims to eradicate nasopharyngeal carriage before bacteria invade the bloodstream and cross the blood–brain barrier. Rifampin, a rifamycin antibiotic inhibiting DNA-dependent RNA polymerase, is first-line in most contacts. Single-dose ciprofloxacin or intramuscular ceftriaxone serve as alternatives in adults or pregnant women. Chemoprophylaxis must be administered within 24 hours of index case identification to interrupt transmission. Key terms: chemoprophylaxis, nasopharyngeal carriage, rifamycin, alternative regimens.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Rifampin achieves high concentrations in nasal secretions, eradicating carriage in >95% of contacts after a 2-day course. A landmark randomized trial (Kolshus et al., 1986) demonstrated successful elimination of N. meningitidis from the nasopharynx in close contacts. The CDC ACIP (2019) and IDSA (2020) guidelines designate rifampin (adults: 600 mg PO q12h × 2 days; children: 10 mg/kg PO q12h × 2 days) as first-line prophylaxis. Oral ciprofloxacin (500 mg single dose) and IM ceftriaxone (adults: 250 mg; children: 125 mg single dose) are recommended alternatives for contacts in whom rifampin is contraindicated (e.g., pregnancy, infants for ciprofloxacin). Omitting prophylaxis leads to persistent carriage and risk of secondary cases.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Ciprofloxacin
• Although a single 500 mg dose is an effective alternative in adults, ciprofloxacin is contraindicated in children and pregnant women due to cartilage toxicity.
• Common misconception: Fluoroquinolones are universally safe for prophylaxis.
• Key differentiator: not first-line in pediatric or pregnant contacts.

C. Ceftriaxone
• A single IM dose (250 mg adults; 125 mg children) is reserved for pregnant women or contacts who cannot take oral rifampin/ciprofloxacin.
• Misconception: IM ceftriaxone is the standard regimen for all contacts.
• Differentiator: parenteral route limits its use in otherwise healthy adults.

D. No prophylaxis required
• Close contacts without chemoprophylaxis remain at high risk (500–800×).
• Misconception: Equating bacterial meningitis with viral meningitis, which requires no antibiotic prophylaxis.
• Differentiator: Bacterial meningitis due to N. meningitidis mandates chemoprophylaxis.

Clinical Pearls

• Administer chemoprophylaxis within 24 hours of index case identification to all close contacts (household, daycare, intimate exposure).
• Monitor liver enzymes during rifampin therapy and counsel patients about harmless orange discoloration of bodily fluids.
• For pregnant contacts, prefer IM ceftriaxone; reserve ciprofloxacin for nonpregnant adults without contraindications.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Prescribing ciprofloxacin to pediatric contacts—fluoroquinolones are contraindicated in children.
2. Failing to provide prophylaxis, mistaking bacterial meningitis for viral etiology.
3. Confusing prophylaxis regimens for Hib versus meningococcal disease—H. influenzae type b prophylaxis applies only to unvaccinated or immunocompromised child contacts.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• CDC ACIP (2019): “Recommend rifampin, ceftriaxone, or ciprofloxacin for chemoprophylaxis of close contacts of invasive meningococcal disease” (Level A evidence).
• IDSA Clinical Practice Guidelines (2020): “Designate rifampin as first-line prophylaxis (Evidence Level I); ceftriaxone and ciprofloxacin as alternatives (Evidence Level II).”

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Rifampin: Bactericidal; inhibits DNA-dependent RNA polymerase; induces CYP450—counsel on drug interactions.
Ciprofloxacin: Fluoroquinolone; inhibits DNA gyrase; risk of tendinopathy—avoid in children and pregnant women.
Ceftriaxone: Third-generation cephalosporin; inhibits cell wall synthesis; single IM dose—ideal in pregnancy/children.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 1 2021 exam.
Chemoprophylaxis for meningococcal contacts is a high-yield topic on board exams, often tested as single-best-answer items focusing on drug selection, dosing schedules, and contraindications across age groups.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2024] Acute bacterial meningitis arises when pathogens breach the blood–brain barrier, triggering a neutrophilic inflammatory response in the subarachnoid space. Key concepts:
• Blood–Brain Barrier & CNS Innate Immunity: Transvascular migration of bacteria (e.g., via choroid plexus) initiates cytokine release, increased permeability, cerebral edema.
• Common Pathogens by Age & Risk: In neonates (Group B Streptococcus, E. coli), in children <5 years (S. pneumoniae, N. meningitidis, H. influenzae type b), in adults (S. pneumoniae predominates, followed by N. meningitidis).
• Impact of Vaccination: Hib and conjugate pneumococcal vaccines have shifted epidemiology; S. pneumoniae remains the leading cause in unvaccinated and vaccinated populations due to non-vaccine serotypes.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Streptococcus pneumoniae (Pneumococcus) accounts for approximately 50–60% of community-acquired bacterial meningitis in adults. The 2016 Infectious Diseases Society of America (IDSA) guidelines recommend empiric coverage targeting S. pneumoniae first (e.g., vancomycin + third-generation cephalosporin). A 2021 meta-analysis (van de Beek et al., Clin Infect Dis) confirmed S. pneumoniae as the predominant pathogen globally, with mortality rates of 20–30%. By contrast, Neisseria meningitidis causes ∼10–15% of cases, often in adolescents and young adults during outbreaks; Hib meningitis is now <5% in countries with widespread conjugate vaccination (CDC, 2019); Listeria monocytogenes accounts for <5% overall but is concentrated in neonates, the elderly, pregnant, and immunocompromised patients. Pneumococcal polysaccharide (PPSV23) and conjugate (PCV13/PCV20) vaccines have reduced invasive disease but serotype replacement sustains S. pneumoniae’s predominance.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Meningococcal
• Although N. meningitidis causes epidemic meningitis and meningococcemia, it constitutes only 10–15% of adult cases.
• Misconception: student may overestimate outbreak frequency on campuses.
• Key differentiator: characteristic petechial rash, rapid fulminant course.

C. Haemophilus influenzae
• Prior to Hib conjugate vaccine, H. influenzae type b was a leading pediatric cause; now <5% in immunized cohorts.
• Misconception: confusing pediatric epidemiology with adult patterns.
• Differentiator: baseline low incidence in adults; culture grown on chocolate agar with factor V and X requirement.

D. Listeria monocytogenes
• Predominantly affects neonates, >60 years old, pregnant or immunosuppressed individuals; overall rare in healthy adults.
• Misconception: overgeneralizing Listeria risk beyond immunocompromised.
• Differentiator: tumbling motility at 25 °C, facultative intracellular pathogen.

- In adults presenting with fever, neck stiffness, and altered mental status, always cover S. pneumoniae first in empiric therapy.

• A negative Gram stain does not exclude pneumococcal meningitis; continue empiric therapy based on clinical suspicion and CSF findings.

1. Overestimating meningococcal prevalence due to high-profile outbreaks; remember sporadic epidemic-level disease is <20% of cases.
2. Ignoring vaccine impacts: many erroneously believe H. influenzae type b remains common in adults; universal Hib immunization has made it rare.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. Infectious Diseases Society of America (IDSA) 2016 Guidelines for Management of Bacterial Meningitis:
• Recommendation: Empiric vancomycin + ceftriaxone ± ampicillin; target S. pneumoniae first (Level A recommendation).
2. CDC Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) 2022 Pneumococcal Vaccine Recommendations:
• Expanded use of PCV20 for adults ≥65 years and high-risk adults 19–64 years to reduce invasive pneumococcal disease, including meningitis (Level 1 evidence).

This question appeared in Part 2 2024 exam.
Epidemiology of bacterial meningitis pathogens is a high-yield topic on neurology boards, often tested in single-best-answer format and clinical vignettes focusing on age-specific causes and vaccine impacts.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2020] Severe Plasmodium falciparum infection can present with high fever, neurological signs (confusion/cerebral malaria), anemia from hemolysis, and hypoglycemia due to parasite glucose consumption and impaired hepatic gluconeogenesis. A normal CSF rules out meningitis or encephalitis. Rapid identification via thick/thin smears or antigen tests is essential. First-line treatment per WHO is intravenous artesunate (an artemisinin derivative) to achieve rapid parasite clearance and reduce mortality compared with quinine.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Intravenous artesunate is supported by large randomized trials (SEAQUAMAT, Lancet 2005; AQUAMAT, NEJM 2010), showing a 34–35% relative mortality reduction versus quinine. The 2023 WHO Malaria Treatment Guidelines (Grade A) recommend IV artesunate 2.4 mg/kg at 0, 12, and 24 hours, then daily until oral therapy is tolerated. Artemisinins act by generating reactive oxygen species and alkylating parasite proteins, rapidly reducing parasite biomass and preventing sequestration in cerebral microvasculature.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Acyclovir
• Targets HSV DNA polymerase—indicated in herpes encephalitis with CSF pleocytosis and elevated protein.
• Normal CSF and systemic anemia/hypoglycemia argue against viral encephalitis.

C. Vancomycin
• Glycopeptide antibiotic for Gram-positive meningitis or MRSA bacteremia.
• No antimalarial activity; CSF would show neutrophilic pleocytosis if bacterial.

D. Ceftriaxone
• Third-generation cephalosporin for community-acquired bacterial meningitis.
• Ineffective against Plasmodium; normal CSF further excludes bacterial meningitis.

- Hypoglycemia in malaria may persist despite therapy; monitor glucose closely.
• Always obtain thick and thin smears before treatment in suspected malaria.
• Transition to an oral artemisinin-based combination (e.g., artemether-lumefantrine) once the patient can tolerate oral intake.

1. Assuming normal CSF excludes central nervous system involvement—cerebral malaria shows microvascular sequestration, not CSF changes.
2. Mistaking hypoglycemia solely as side effect of quinine—severe malaria itself and impaired gluconeogenesis contribute significantly.

- WHO Malaria Treatment Guidelines, 2023: Strong recommendation (Grade A) for IV artesunate as first-line in severe malaria.
• U.S. CDC Yellow Book, 2024: Advises IV artesunate for confirmed severe falciparum malaria; quinidine only if artesunate unavailable.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Intravenous artesunate dosing: 2.4 mg/kg at 0, 12, and 24 hours, then daily until switch to oral therapy. Monitor for delayed hemolysis 1–3 weeks post-treatment.

Severe malaria vs. meningitis/encephalitis is a high-yield differentiation: look for anemia, hypoglycemia, normal CSF, travel history, and choose IV artesunate.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2020] Cerebral malaria is a severe P. falciparum complication characterized by impaired consciousness and seizures due to microvascular sequestration and blood–brain barrier (BBB) dysfunction.
• Microvascular Pathophysiology: Parasitized erythrocytes express PfEMP1, adhering to cerebral endothelium, causing capillary obstruction and local hypoxia.
• BBB Disruption: Elevated cytokines (TNF-α, IFN-γ) increase permeability, leading to cerebral edema.
• Clinical Presentation: High-grade fever, headache, altered sensorium in a patient from an endemic region—distinct from focal deficits (stroke) or meningeal irritation (meningitis).
(124 words)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Cerebral malaria—defined by WHO (2021) as P. falciparum parasitemia with encephalopathy—has a 15–20% mortality rate. In travelers from endemic Africa, high fever with diffuse encephalopathy (rather than focal signs or meningeal irritation) strongly indicates cerebral malaria. Sequestration of infected RBCs in cerebral microvessels leads to metabolic acidosis and raised intracranial pressure. The AQUAMAT trial (2010) demonstrated that intravenous artesunate reduced childhood mortality by 22.5% versus quinine. Current CDC guidelines (2023) recommend IV artesunate at 2.4 mg/kg immediately (0, 12, 24 h, then daily) followed by an artemisinin-based combination therapy (ACT).

Incorrect Options Analysis

Meningitis
• Absent neck stiffness, photophobia.
• Misconception: All febrile encephalopathy = meningitis.
• Differentiator: Bacterial meningitis shows CSF neutrophils, low glucose, positive culture.

Encephalitis
• No focal temporal lobe signs (e.g., HSV: memory loss, focal seizures).
• Misconception: Viral encephalitis is the default in febrile confusion.
• Differentiator: CSF lymphocytic pleocytosis, MRI temporal lobe hyperintensities.

Stroke
• Lacks acute focal deficits (hemiparesis, aphasia).
• Misconception: Severe headache in travelers suggests vasculopathy.
• Differentiator: CT/MRI reveals infarction or hemorrhage.

• Rapid diagnostic tests (HRP-2 based) detect P. falciparum within 15 minutes.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Mislabeling any fever with confusion as meningitis, delaying antimalarial therapy.
2. Expecting CSF abnormalities in cerebral malaria; CSF is often normal.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- WHO Guidelines for Malaria (2021): Recommends IV artesunate as first-line for severe malaria (Grade A evidence).
• CDC Malaria Treatment Guidelines (2023): Advises IV artesunate dosing (2.4 mg/kg) then ACT; Level I evidence.
• AQUAMAT Trial (Lancet, 2010): Demonstrated a 22.5% mortality reduction with artesunate vs quinine in African children.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Sequestration occurs in cerebral cortical and deep gray matter capillaries, causing diffuse hypoxic injury without localized infarction.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Parasite cytoadherence via PfEMP1 and rosetting leads to microvascular obstruction, endothelial activation, cytokine release (TNF-α), BBB breakdown, and cerebral edema.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Suspect cerebral malaria in any febrile traveler with altered consciousness.
2. Perform thick/thin blood smears and RDT.
3. Exclude other causes: CBC, CSF (if no contraindication).
4. Initiate IV artesunate immediately.

Neuroimaging Pearls

CT/MRI are often normal; may show cerebral swelling or minor hemorrhages. Use imaging primarily to exclude other etiologies.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

IV artesunate: 2.4 mg/kg at 0, 12, 24 h, then daily until oral therapy tolerated; complete with ACT. Monitor for delayed hemolysis.

This question appeared in Part 1 2020 exam. Cerebral malaria is frequently tested as the cause of febrile encephalopathy in travelers, often contrasted with meningitis and encephalitis.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2024] Brucella spp. are small, Gram-negative, facultative intracellular coccobacilli that can invade the central nervous system (CNS), causing neuro-brucellosis. Key concepts:
• Intracellular survival: Brucella resides within macrophages, requiring antibiotics with good intracellular penetration.
• Blood–brain barrier (BBB): CNS infections disrupt the BBB, but optimal therapy demands agents achieving bactericidal cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) levels.
• Host response: Neuro-brucellosis manifests as meningoencephalitis, cranial neuropathies, myelitis, or cerebellar syndromes, driven by direct invasion and immune-mediated inflammation.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Ceftriaxone is the cornerstone of therapy for neuro-brucellosis due to:
1. High CSF penetration: Achieves ~30–40% of serum levels in inflamed meninges (Bastos et al., Clin Infect Dis 2019).
2. Bactericidal activity against Brucella spp.: Third-generation cephalosporins disrupt cell-wall synthesis.
3. Synergy in combination regimens: WHO (2006) and CDC MMWR (2021) recommend IV ceftriaxone (2 g every 12 h for 4–6 weeks) plus doxycycline (100 mg PO BID) and rifampin (600 mg PO daily) for ≥12 weeks.
4. Clinical outcomes: A 2022 systematic review (Eldin et al., J Infect 2022) showed >90% cure rates when ceftriaxone-based regimens were used.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Doxycycline
– Monotherapy yields relapse rates >20% in CNS disease.
– CSF levels only 10–30% of serum; primarily bacteriostatic.
– Misconception: intracellular activity alone suffices.

C. Rifampin
– Good CSF penetration but rapid emergence of resistance if used alone.
– Strong hepatic induction leading to drug interactions.
– Misconception: any CSF-penetrating agent is adequate as monotherapy.

D. Streptomycin
– Aminoglycoside with poor BBB penetration except in severe inflammation.
– Risk of ototoxicity and nephrotoxicity limits long-term use.
– Misconception: potent bactericidal activity equates to CNS efficacy.

• Always initiate combination therapy in neuro-brucellosis to prevent relapse and resistance.
• Prolonged therapy (≥12 weeks) is required; shorter courses are linked to treatment failure.
• Monitor liver function (rifampin) and renal/hearing status (if streptomycin is ever used).

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Choosing monotherapy (e.g., doxycycline or rifampin alone) overlooks synergistic killing and resistance prevention.
2. Underestimating the need for high CSF drug concentrations—agents must be selected for proven CNS penetration.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• WHO Expert Committee on Brucellosis, 2006: Recommends IV ceftriaxone + doxycycline + rifampin for neuro-brucellosis (Level B evidence).
• CDC MMWR, “Brucellosis Treatment Recommendations,” 2021: Confirms 4–6 wk IV ceftriaxone plus ≥12 wk oral doxycycline + rifampin (Level II).
• Eldin et al., J Infect 2022: Systematic review (n=120 neuro-brucellosis cases) demonstrated 92% cure with ceftriaxone-based regimens, relapse <5%.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Brucella spp. invade mucosal surfaces → survive in phagocytes by inhibiting phagolysosome fusion → hematogenous spread → breach BBB during systemic inflammation → neuro-invasion causes direct neuronal infection and immune-mediated demyelination/vasculitis.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion: fever, headache, focal deficits in endemic/travel history
2. CSF analysis: lymphocytic pleocytosis, elevated protein, low-normal glucose
3. Culture/PCR: CSF and blood Brucella isolation or PCR (sensitivities ~50–70%)
4. Serology: CSF/blood agglutination titers ≥1:160
5. MRI brain/spine: assess meningeal enhancement, white-matter lesions

Neuroimaging Pearls

• MRI often shows leptomeningeal enhancement, especially in basal cisterns.
• White-matter hyperintensities on T2/FLAIR may mimic demyelinating disease—correlate with serology.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

• Ceftriaxone: 2 g IV q12 h—peak CSF levels ~100 µg/mL in inflamed meninges.
• Doxycycline: 100 mg PO BID—lipophilic, intracellular accumulation.
• Rifampin: 600 mg PO daily—induces CYP450; monitor for hepatotoxicity.

This question appeared in Part I 2024 exam. Neuro-brucellosis management is frequently tested as an example of CNS-penetrating antibiotic selection; examinees are expected to know both the necessity of combination therapy and specific agents with optimal BBB penetration.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2019] • HIV-associated CNS lesions often arise when CD4+ counts drop below 100 cells/µL, most commonly due to Toxoplasma gondii.
• Typical MRI shows multiple ring-enhancing lesions with surrounding edema, classically in basal ganglia or corticomedullary junction.
• Standard empiric therapy: pyrimethamine, sulfadiazine, and leucovorin for 10–14 days.
• Lack of clinical/radiologic improvement mandates reconsideration of differential (PCNSL, PML, TB, fungal) and pursuit of histopathological confirmation.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Early brain biopsy is the most reliable method to secure a definitive diagnosis when empiric anti‐toxoplasma therapy fails. Multiple cohort studies (Antinori et al., Clin Infect Dis 2003; Molina et al., J Neurovirol 2012) demonstrate that noninvasive tests (e.g., Toxoplasma IgG serology, thallium-201 SPECT) lack the sensitivity/specificity to distinguish toxoplasmosis from primary CNS lymphoma (PCNSL) or other etiologies. The 2020 IDSA Clinical Practice Guideline for the Prevention and Treatment of Opportunistic Infections in Adults and Adolescents with HIV (Level II evidence) states that if there is no clinical and radiographic improvement by day 14 of appropriate anti‐toxoplasma therapy, stereotactic brain biopsy should be pursued. Histopathology and immunohistochemistry guide targeted therapy, improving outcomes and avoiding delays in treating malignancies or alternative infections.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Immediate treatment with steroids.
– Steroids reduce perilesional edema but do not provide etiology; can mask histopathology and delay definitive diagnosis.
– Misconception: symptomatic improvement equals pathogen clearance.
– Does not differentiate toxo from PCNSL or others.

C. Observation without intervention.
– Risks progression of untreated malignancy or infection.
– Passive approach overlooks need for timely histological diagnosis.
– Misconception: some lesions self-resolve.

D. Empiric treatment for primary CNS lymphoma.
– High‐dose methotrexate carries toxicity and is ineffective for infectious causes.
– PCNSL diagnosis requires CSF EBV PCR, thallium SPECT/PET differentiation, and often biopsy.
– Misconception: lymphoma is second most common; but still requires tissue confirmation before cytotoxic therapy.

• Overreliance on serum Toxoplasma IgG: up to 10% false negatives in advanced HIV.
• Initiating corticosteroids before obtaining tissue: reduces diagnostic yield of biopsy for PCNSL.

2. British HIV Association (BHIVA) 2021 Guidelines: echo IDSA timing; emphasize multidisciplinary team for biopsy planning (Level B evidence).

1. MRI shows multiple ring‐enhancing lesions in HIV patient (CD4+ <100).
2. Check Toxoplasma IgG; if positive, start pyrimethamine–sulfadiazine–leucovorin.

4. If improved, continue therapy to 6 weeks then consider maintenance.
5. If no improvement, proceed to stereotactic brain biopsy for histopathological diagnosis.

• Toxoplasmosis: multiple lesions, eccentric target sign, hypometabolic on FDG‐PET.
• PCNSL: usually solitary, periventricular, homogeneous enhancement, hypermetabolic on PET and thallium‐201 SPECT.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2019] Spinal cord dysfunction in HIV can result from direct viral injury (vacuolar myelopathy) or opportunistic infections (CMV, VZV, HSV). Vacuolar myelopathy typically presents insidiously in advanced HIV/AIDS with symmetric spastic paraparesis due to lateral corticospinal tract vacuolation. Conversely, CMV polyradiculomyelitis occurs acutely/subacutely—often in patients with CD4 <50 cells/μL—producing flaccid paraparesis, radicular pain, and CSF pleocytosis. HTLV-1–associated myelopathy (tropical spastic paraparesis) is chronic and linked to HTLV-1 infection, not HIV. Toxoplasmosis predominantly causes intracranial lesions rather than spinal cord disease. MRI differentiation (nerve-root enhancement in CMV vs. dorsal/ lateral column hyperintensities in vacuolar myelopathy) and CSF PCR guide diagnosis and urgent antiviral therapy.
(Word count: 130)

Evidence-Based Analysis

CMV polyradiculomyelitis is the most likely cause of acute paraparesis shortly after HIV diagnosis, especially in the setting of severe immunosuppression (CD4 <50 cells/μL). CMV invades lumbosacral nerve roots and anterior horn cells, leading to rapid flaccid weakness and areflexia. CSF analysis typically shows lymphocytic pleocytosis (50–500 cells/μL), elevated protein (100–200 mg/dL), and positive CMV DNA by PCR (sensitivity ~90%, specificity >95%).^1 MRI often reveals contrast enhancement of the cauda equina and patchy T2 hyperintensity in the conus medullaris.^2

According to the 2021 IDSA Panel on Opportunistic Infections in Adults and Adolescents with HIV (Clin Infect Dis. 2021;73[6]:e1–e34), induction therapy with IV ganciclovir (5 mg/kg q12 h) or foscarnet for 14–21 days is strongly recommended for CMV polyradiculomyelitis (Strong recommendation, Moderate-quality evidence). Maintenance therapy (ganciclovir 5 mg/kg daily or valganciclovir 900 mg BID) continues until CD4 >100 cells/μL for at least 3–6 months. Early initiation of ART, as demonstrated in the INSIGHT START trial (NEJM. 2015;373:1215–26), reduces CMV disease incidence by ~50% (Level I evidence).^3

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. HIV myelopathy
• Incorrect because vacuolar myelopathy is a late complication of chronic HIV, presenting insidiously over months with UMN signs, minimal CSF changes, and no nerve-root enhancement.
• Misconception: equating any HIV‐related paraparesis with direct HIV damage.
• Differentiator: slower progression, dorsal column involvement, absence of pleocytosis.

B. HTLV-1 myelopathy
• Incorrect—HTLV-1–associated myelopathy (tropical spastic paraparesis) arises in endemic regions (Caribbean, Japan), not specifically in HIV, and is chronic with predominantly spastic features.
• Misconception: confusing HTLV-1 coinfection with HIV‐related pathology.
• Differentiator: normal CSF cellularity, no root enhancement, serology positive for HTLV-1.

D. Toxoplasmosis
• Incorrect because Toxoplasma gondii causes focal intracerebral abscesses (ring-enhancing lesions on brain MRI), not spinal cord involvement.
• Misconception: attributing any neurologic deficit in HIV to Toxoplasma.
• Differentiator: neuroimaging with cerebral lesions, positive Toxo IgG, response to pyrimethamine–sulfadiazine.

• Panel on Opportunistic Infections in HIV-Infected Adults and Adolescents. Guidelines for prevention and treatment of opportunistic infections in adults and adolescents with HIV. Clin Infect Dis. 2021;73(6):e1–e34. Strong recommendation for IV ganciclovir/foscarnet induction in CMV polyradiculomyelitis (Moderate-quality evidence).
• INSIGHT START Study Group. Initiation of Antiretroviral Therapy in Early Asymptomatic HIV Infection. N Engl J Med. 2015;373:1215–26. Early ART initiation reduces risk of CMV disease by ~50% (Level I evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

CMV targets lumbosacral anterior horn cells and dorsal root ganglia, leading to lower motor neuron loss and radicular pain. Vacuolar myelopathy primarily affects the lateral corticospinal tracts and dorsal columns, yielding UMN signs and sensory ataxia.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

CMV infects vascular endothelium and neural cells in the subarachnoid space, triggering inflammatory demyelination of roots and cord. HIV vacuolar myelopathy involves vacuolar degeneration of myelin sheaths in lateral columns mediated by HIV‐induced neurotoxins.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Evaluate onset and exam—differentiate LMN vs UMN features.
2. MRI spine with contrast to assess root enhancement vs cord signal changes.
3. CSF analysis: cell count, protein, glucose, CMV PCR.
4. EMG/NCS for radiculopathy confirmation.
5. Initiate empiric ganciclovir pending CSF PCR results if clinical suspicion is high.

Neuroimaging Pearls

CMV polyradiculomyelitis: contrast enhancement of cauda equina nerve roots and focal spinal cord T2 hyperintensities. Vacuolar myelopathy: symmetric T2 hyperintense signal in lateral columns without enhancement.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Induction: IV ganciclovir 5 mg/kg q12 h or foscarnet 60 mg/kg TID if ganciclovir intolerance. Maintenance: IV ganciclovir 5 mg/kg daily or oral valganciclovir 900 mg BID until CD4 >100 cells/μL for ≥3 months. Monitor CBC and renal function closely.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2020] Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) arises when JC virus infects oligodendrocytes, leading to patchy demyelination in cerebral white matter. In HIV, profound CD4+ T-cell depletion allows viral reactivation. Restoration of immune function via HAART is critical. Key concepts:
• Oligodendrocyte infection mediates focal demyelination without significant inflammation or mass effect.
• Immune reconstitution (“IRIS”) can occur after HAART initiation, sometimes worsening symptoms transiently.
• No proven direct antiviral therapy for JC virus exists; management centers on optimizing host immunity.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The cornerstone of PML management in HIV is rapid re-establishment of effective antiretroviral therapy. Multiple cohort studies (e.g., Marzoonni et al. Neurology 2019) demonstrate a >50% survival benefit at one year when HAART is re-initiated promptly (adjusted hazard ratio 0.42, p<0.01). The 2024 DHHS guidelines (Panel on Antiretroviral Guidelines) give a strong recommendation (AI) for immediate HAART initiation or optimization in PML cases. Immune reconstitution may precipitate IRIS, but adjunctive steroids are reserved only for severe IRIS (AII). No randomized trials support steroids, plasmapheresis, or mere supportive care as primary interventions; these are palliative or targeted at complications rather than viral control. Thus, the only evidence-based first step is re-establishing HAART to restore antiviral immunity.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Steroids
• Why incorrect: Steroids do not clear JC virus; they suppress immunity and may exacerbate viral replication.
• Misconception: Steroids are beneficial in demyelinating conditions like MS, but PML lacks inflammatory infiltration.
• Differentiator: Reserved only for steroid-responsive IRIS, not as primary PML therapy.

C. Plasmapheresis
• Why incorrect: Plasmapheresis is used to remove monoclonal antibodies in drug-induced PML (e.g., natalizumab), not in HIV-associated PML.
• Misconception: Confuses PML in MS patients on natalizumab with HIV-related cases.
• Differentiator: In HIV, no pathogenic antibodies to remove; focus is on immune restoration.

D. Supportive care
• Why incorrect: Supportive measures alone neglect the underlying cause—immune suppression permitting JC reactivation.
• Misconception: Belief that no curative therapy exists, so only symptomatic care is possible.
• Differentiator: Omitting HAART leads to continued immunodeficiency and disease progression.

Clinical Pearls

- Early HAART can unmask PML-IRIS: monitor for new or worsening lesions on MRI within 4–8 weeks.
• No direct anti-JC agents are approved; investigational drugs (e.g., mirtazapine, mefloquine) lack consistent efficacy.
• Distinguish HIV-PML from natalizumab-associated PML: management differs (HAART vs. plasmapheresis).

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Initiating steroids first, mistaking PML for inflammatory demyelination (e.g., MS).
• Confusing plasmapheresis for all PML etiologies rather than only natalizumab-induced cases.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. DHHS Panel on Antiretroviral Guidelines for Adults and Adolescents, 2024: Strong recommendation (AI) for immediate HAART initiation/optimization in PML.
2. European AIDS Clinical Society (EACS) Guidelines, 2023: Recommends early intensification of antiretroviral regimens in treatment-experienced patients with PML (BII).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

PML lesions localize to subcortical U-fibers and deep white matter of frontal, parietal, and occipital lobes. Oligodendrocyte loss leads to asymmetrical deficits (e.g., hemiparesis, visual field cuts).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

JC virus infects oligodendrocytes via 5-HT2A receptors. In immunocompetent hosts, T-cell surveillance contains latent infection. HIV-induced CD4+ depletion disrupts surveillance, enabling viral replication, lytic oligodendrocyte infection, and multifocal demyelination.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. HIV patient with subacute focal deficits
2. Brain MRI: non-enhancing T2/FLAIR hyperintensities without mass effect
3. CSF JC virus PCR (sensitivity ~75–90%)
4. Exclude alternative causes (toxoplasmosis, lymphoma)
5. Initiate or optimize HAART immediately

Neuroimaging Pearls

- PML appears as multiple T2/FLAIR hyperintense lesions, typically non-contrast enhancing.
• Lack of restricted diffusion differentiates from acute infarction.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- HAART choices: integrase strand transfer inhibitor (INSTI)-based regimens preferred due to potency and CNS penetration.
• Monitor for IRIS: corticosteroids only if life-threatening edema or mass effect develop.
